awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Refining foraminiferal I/Ca as a paleoceanographic oxygenation proxy for the glacial Atlantic Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project seeks to refine the use of I/Ca ratios in fossil foraminifera from marine sediments as a proxy for reconstructing past dissolved oxygen levels in the ocean, a fundamental variable because of the role oxygen plays in the biogeochemical cycle of carbon and in controlling the distribution of marine life. The present oceans because of warming and eutrophication are on a trajectory to lower oxygen contents and future expansion of marine "dead zones" - regions where waters have oxygen levels below the threshold necessary for life. Ocean-wide changes in dissolved oxygen levels that are projected to occur over the next century are expected to have magnitudes similar to those that occurred over the natural glacial-interglacial cycles of the last few millions of years. A better understanding of the ocean's oxygen history in the past, especially the geographic and bathymetric extent of oxygen depletion, can help improve future forecasts. While a number of geochemical proxies are available to reconstruct extreme oxygen changes that affected the whole or large parts of the global ocean in the distant geological past, proxies sensitive to the subtler oxygen fluctuations expected to occur in the near-future have been lacking. Measurements of foraminiferal I/Ca in preliminary studies have shown excellent potential to differentiate and reconstruct intermediate oxygen levels in the water column. This project will further evaluate and refine I/Ca as a quantitative proxy for reconstructing hypoxic and suboxic conditions, oxygen levels most relevant to future threats to marine ecosystems on a human time scale. Broader impacts of the project include the support of an early career scientist and two senior PIs, as well as two graduate students and several undergraduates. Public outreach will be through collaboration with the local Syracuse Science Museum and through the mainstream media. 

The project team will conduct I/Ca analyses of foraminifera from a large suite of core top samples from the west Africa margin to further develop empirical calibrations between iodine and subsurface oxygen levels. They will compare I/Ca data with two independent oxygen proxies (nitrogen isotope data and carbon isotope gradients in benthic foraminifera), targeting both the upper and deep oceans. The team will then apply I/Ca measurements to downcore planktic and benthic foraminifera from a variety of regions in the Atlantic and Southern Ocean to quantitatively reconstruct past variations in the distribution and intensity of the oxygen minimum zone (OMZ), with a focus on changes in the glacial ocean at different depths and in different parts of the Atlantic basin. In addition, a representation of the marine iodine cycle will be incorporated into a widely-used Earth System Model (cGENIE), enabling explicit data-model comparisons for the first time. Graduate and postgraduate training in earth system modeling will be provided through a two-day workshop to be held at Syracuse University. This project will lead to further develop of a promising proxy (I/Ca) for hypoxic and suboxic conditions, investigate the variability of ocean oxygenation with climate change, and advance the capacity for future integration between proxy oxygen data and earth system models.

por.por_cntn:
All animals in the oceans need oxygen to survive and thrive, and oxygen levels are thus of great importance for human activities such as fisheries. Oxygen is less soluble in warm water than in colder water, and one could thus expect that oxygen levels in the oceans would become lower in a warmer world. There is indeed evidence that global warming is inducing lower oxygen levels, and we would like to be able to predict future effects of global warming. However, such predictions are in reality very difficult, because oxygen levels are not only simply dependent upon temperature only, but determined by the interplay between complex physical, chemical and biological processes. If the ocean waters are strongly layered due to differences in density, it is more difficult to mix in oxygen from the atmosphere, so we need to know about ocean strtatification and circulation. Even more complex, in the sunlit surface waters the microscopic plants which are the base of the food chain in the oceans are photosynthesizing, producing oxygen and organic matter, which forms their bosies. Parts of this organic matter is not eaten by animals, but sinks and rots, and uses up oxygen in the rotting process. We thus can predict the effect of global warming on oxygen levels of the oceans only if we have sufficient understanding of the effects of warming on ocean stratification and circulation as well as on biological processes. 

We used the chemical composition of shells of recently living and fossil organisms as a tracer (proxy) for oxygen contents of seawater in which the shells form, and thus aimed to reconstruct oxygen levels in the oceans as they changed over periods of changing climate, and incorporated the data in an Earth System Model for better understanding of the complex processes. We used the information on the recently living forms to link the shell-composition to recent oxygen levels, then used the information to extrapolate to the past.  Specifically, we collected the calciumcarbonate shells of microscopic unicellular organisms which live either floating in the surface waters  (planktic foraminifera) or on the sea floor (benthic foraminifera) and analyzed them for their iodine content, using samples from different parts of the oceans, many from the Atlantic Ocean. The iodine content is a proxy for oxygen levels, although there are complexities in the linkages between iodine levels and shell concentration. We studied these complexities, and worked on reconstructions of oxygen levels in differentvparts of the world's oceans, during the last ice age, continuing over the period of melting of the ice sheets during the transition to the modern interglacial period, called the Holocene. 

Our modeling results indicate that ocean circulation changes in the Atlantic Ocean, specifically increased importance of northern-sourced waters and increasing ventilation, thus increasing oxygenation of the deep ocean, may have controlled the vertical distribution of [O2] in the ocean during the warming at the end of the last ice age. These modeling results suggest that no simple and predictable relationship between past climate state and oxygenation may exist, and thus that predicting oxygen levels from climate state alone will not be possible: we will need to gain understanding of the interlinking factors of climate state, and the response of oceanic circulation and life forms (patterns of both photosynthesis and rotting)  to these factors.
